<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-v3g4';
	}
</script>

<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/Unit42-blog-2by1-characters-r4d1-2020_New-mirai-variant-v3.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Mirai Variant V3G4 Targets IoT Devices","name":"Mirai Variant V3G4 Targets IoT Devices","description":"We observed Mirai variant V3G4 targeting IoT devices in three separate campaigns in 2022.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/mirai-variant-v3g4\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/mirai-variant-v3g4\/","datePublished":"February 15, 2023","articleBody":"Content Warning\r\nWe are providing a content warning because the following contains usage of a racial slur by a threat actor, which is not condoned in any instance by Unit 42. Unit 42 has partially redacted the racial slur to provide researchers with the ability to identify it and check IoCs as needed.\r\nExecutive Summary\r\nFrom July to December 2022, Unit 42 researchers observed a Mirai variant called V3G4, which was leveraging several vulnerabilities to spread itself. The vulnerabilities exploited include the following:\r\n\r\n \tCVE-2012-4869: FreePBX Elastix Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tGitorious Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2014-9727: FRITZ!Box Webcam Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tMitel AWC Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2017-5173: Geutebruck IP Cameras Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2019-15107: Webmin Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n \tSpree Commerce Arbitrary Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tFLIR Thermal Camera Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2020-8515: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2020-15415: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2022-36267: Airspan AirSpot Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2022-26134: Atlassian Confluence Remote Code Execution Vulnerability\r\n \tCVE-2022-4257: C-Data Web Management System Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n\r\nOnce the vulnerable devices are compromised, they will be fully controlled by attackers and become a part of the botnet. The threat actor has the capability to utilize those devices to conduct further attacks, such as distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks. The exploit attempts captured by Unit 42 researchers leverage the aforementioned vulnerabilities to spread V3G4, which targets exposed servers and networking devices running Linux.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks Next-Generation Firewall customers receive protections through cloud-delivered security services such as IoT Security, Advanced Threat Prevention, WildFire, and Advanced URL Filtering, which can help detect and block the exploit traffic and malware.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nMirai, IoT\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCampaign Overview\r\nSince July 2022, Unit 42 researchers have observed three campaigns utilizing the Mirai V3G4 variant. Based on our analysis, we believe the campaigns were operated by the same threat actor for the following reasons:\r\n\r\n \tThe hardcoded command and control (C2) domains among these three campaigns contain the same string (8xl9)\r\n \tThe malware shell script downloaders are almost identical between the three campaigns\r\n \tThe botnet client samples use the same XOR decryption key\r\n \tThe botnet client samples use the same \u201cstop list\u201d (a list of target processes that the botnet client searches for and terminates)\r\n \tThe botnet client samples use almost identical functions\r\n\r\nThe threat actor exploited 13 vulnerabilities that could lead to remote code execution. Upon successful exploitation, the wget and curl utilities are automatically executed to download Mirai client samples from malware infrastructure and then execute the downloaded bot clients.\r\n\r\nThe utilized vulnerabilities are listed in Figure 1 below, and the detailed vulnerability information is listed in the Appendix section.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126929\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"781\"] Figure 1. V3G4 Campaign Overview.[\/caption]\r\nV3G4 Malware Analysis\r\nBased on behavior and patterns Unit 42 researchers observed during analysis of the downloaded botnet client samples, we believe that the botnet sample is a variant of the Mirai botnet.\r\n\r\nUpon execution, the botnet client prints xXxSlicexXxxVEGA. to the console. The malware also contains a function that makes sure only one instance of this malware is executing on the infected device. If a botnet process already exists, the botnet client will simply print a string from the console and exit, as depicted in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126931\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"266\"] Figure 2. V3G4 ensures single instance execution.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe botnet client also contains a list of process names, and it tries to terminate those processes by checking the running process names on the infected host. The process names in that list belong to other botnet malware families and other Mirai variants. The full stop list is shown in Figure 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126933\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"670\"] Figure 3. V3G4\u2019s stop list.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe V3G4 variant tries to connect to its hardcoded C2. This activity is shown in Figure 4.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126935\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"473\"] Figure 4. V3G4 malware C2 domain.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nMost Mirai variants use the same key for string encryption. However, this V3G4 variant uses different XOR encryption keys for different scenarios.\r\nBotnet Client Execution-Related String Decryption\r\nFor strings related to botnet client execution, this V3G4 variant will first initialize an encrypted string table. It will then retrieve the encrypted string through an index (shown in Figures 5 and 6).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126937\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"535\"] Figure 5. Encrypted string table.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126939\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. V3G4 retrieves strings.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAll the botnet client execution-related strings are decrypted with four rounds of XOR decryption (shown in Figure 7). The decryption keys used are the following:\r\n\r\n \tFirst round: 0xbc\r\n \tSecond round: 0x69\r\n \tThird round: 0x3a\r\n \tFourth round: 0xe6\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126941\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"469\"] Figure 7. V3G4 four rounds of XOR decryption.[\/caption]\r\nBrute Force Credential String Decryption\r\nV3G4 inherits its most significant feature from the original Mirai variant \u2013 a data section with embedded default login credentials for the scanner and brute force purposes. Like the original Mirai, it also encrypts all credentials with XOR key 0x37.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126943\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"300\"] Figure 8. V3G4 credentials XOR Decryption.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe V3G4 variant initializes the table of telnet\/SSH login credentials in the scanner function. It then spreads itself through brute forcing network devices\u2019 weak username\/password combinations.\r\n\r\nBefore the botnet client establishes a connection with the C2 server, the malware will first initialize all DDoS attack functions (shown in Figure 9). Once the client establishes a connection with the C2 server, the threat actor can issue commands to the client to launch DDoS attacks.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126945\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"258\"] Figure 9. V3G4 DDoS functions.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWe also noticed that the malware samples from the three campaigns we observed are slightly different. The original Mirai botnet sample spread itself by brute-forcing weak telnet\/SSH credentials, whereas some Mirai variants utilize both brute-force and embedded exploits to spread themselves. However, samples from the September and December 2022 campaigns don\u2019t contain the functions of vulnerability exploitation and brute force of credentials (this is shown in Figure 10).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126947\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 10. Campaign samples comparison.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nThe vulnerabilities mentioned above have less attack complexity than previously observed variants, but they maintain a critical security impact that can lead to remote code execution. Once the attacker gains control of a vulnerable device in this manner, they could take advantage by including the newly compromised devices in their botnet to conduct further attacks such as DDoS. Therefore, it is highly recommended that patches and updates are applied when possible.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive protection from the vulnerabilities and malware discussed above through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tNext-Generation Firewalls with a Threat Prevention security subscription can help block the attacks with Best Practices via Threat Prevention signatures 56254, 56954, 92632, 55935, 55933, 58668, 35131, 55798, 57897, 56256, 55934, 93332 and 93392.\r\n \tAdvanced Threat Prevention has an inbuilt machine learning-based detection that can detect vulnerability exploits in real-time.\r\n \tWildFire can help stop the malware with static signature detections.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and DNS Security are able to block the C2 domain and malware-hosting URLs.\r\n \tThe Palo Alto Networks IoT Security platform can leverage network traffic information to identify the vendor, model and firmware version of a device and identify specific devices that are vulnerable to particular CVEs.\r\n \tIn addition, IoT Security has inbuilt machine learning-based anomaly detection that can alert the customer if a device exhibits nontypical behavior such as a sudden appearance of traffic from a new source, an unusually high number of connections or an inexplicable surge of certain attributes typically appearing in IoT application payloads.\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nInfrastructure\r\nMalware C2\r\n\r\n\r\ncomeanalyze.8x19[.]com\r\nMalware Host\r\n176.123.9[.]238\r\n198.98.49[.]79\r\n104.244.72[.]64\r\nArtifacts\r\nShell Script Downloader\r\n0837de91aa6bd52ef79d744daba4238a5a48a79eb91cb1a727da3e97d5b36329\r\nc32f8df3cb019e83e0ac49ab0462c59ec70733c3d516ade011727408751c9d42\r\nf295904d966889afb0f6b3625e504a1420a978434e2b6a9e9b85b688a44593fa\r\nV3G4 Sample\r\nJuly Campaign\r\n\r\n7bc99c87a1e0582b5f15f40141226862fbe726b496e1e77c7f95993e8e945733\r\n88f7b9a8c4f9bb28582c485549b328d6123e8aea33009ce7657f7fc0ef829e03\r\n64545e94daafba191669333e1dd0c6e1190df47e0742bd515911cce0cdbd4fd1\r\n69bb44736817dabe88e3014c6207ba702f644fb43f6feaec23091af0b5224bc6\r\neaa387fcc12f2d8a7d42f12d27e7dccb4f3e11492a7d3a3a1ce830a11b539d28\r\na987d1e113b858d21596bb2dfffe79721d5149bfa782e693aafc0cf47aa8c6dc\r\nafca95eb143e0180f1594517a44b2d226a2e44de5cbd2cd49b8c6cdb2a0b61ee\r\nb651f9320f07d7eade9af523297b4bcfd0e0af187272e368e889c988a55ed78e\r\n6229041985c466c131e48b9ba0d1bb80bdb7556c941ee84aa461fe2efbf1e853\r\n1dc4777dac6dc4e8c650241e211311c4a418a35ebded72fcdd6bcb965ccf918b\r\n3e69e8ed741ab39b0914f7e95bf13b2f0ae9f3c1227dcffdea3369e03e8bb792\r\nb2e4ee94783062658ddf2c41e9acafb401d0f93e3848c027383a5ca19289b786\r\ndd91943b0d453ace3b19779c88da19c9a386dd3e9d2322c85a4cdcf84a22c663\r\na93d999dc0515066c5c2a261f1be47233b358889d0594c14409309818d86347d\r\n\r\nSeptember Campaign\r\n\r\n31926da5ca004a11c1f46947edb220afe3a53f81cf245b3afae7ea1abaec7c38\r\need4690f6e4d92b511fcde9a712b1a8405c5333e0ad78a4c676a64b22412e149\r\n210f3f1ffd2ec66a5076a7fea5d83caa8bbcdb0f3bc3bd030c77eded6f4b5d90\r\n73cc00acc478bf09658a679a4689f34598fe6e92086efe82900242f3cc5b7aec\r\n1218da43a62da76927484bca73a3eee53425c54625147f8d01149bcef2f09d1e\r\n2944db28e4505fc439599dae15b10bf57b7cf6c2597f618f41b99bfc65443c61\r\n4bffc171c0748cc9e3398b1ce8135b125f54f46752768c981c45d3390e8359a1\r\nb3a17934f6f72941b9a60097ab09228d873a2f8737ee0ea93b08e5f1cc3916d1\r\n916e00391279b014e53d73c2216a84bd528e18f1f633ba0101288aa963f77c5b\r\n7dea8dac3f455f3a57fecfa5a047439126556858c239e73cd8feec2dc13bae2c\r\na10ce475f64f3821ab32c88f6b013effd40843dd575ceaab46a57f134c2478b6\r\nd9b5199f36fc416d8a87d798926e0d9dcbb2fe97610cf08d6887dae1355e9439\r\nfeda096ed8ddf4206365d326b3b7cb2d57ca1e89999b0b1da80fb9658dff6e44\r\n\r\nDecember Campaign:\r\n\r\n63ACD589A53BDEC49C624F3CB2FC8319218DF721F486E2F15F3C07ABED97AAE6\r\n1cf3879d9e93d1ff30ce5ec0f64ff15b1db7d8237160c83efed688d800e5ef12\r\nc5be50880e2b5a8a8d43a5f1fd6f5d36fc665ab9b4031a9b6a4d52222004c2c1\r\n9b7f36cabbb90dfe9cd75f12c01fb64766dd1ec0f4247dbf8f4477dd64407fbf\r\n7d9cdf3afb1d52f49d82b1ffe28a3da08c6aeeaa8c5047ba37c73802d2cd9ec2\r\n9a0d39265b53e1959df49dbc8727ad344abc12a8bc0bd8d8b76f8b150525dca6\r\nd00fbfc439cb9c5c850690134b0d51f262021c0d04d9934df464980c346c1dc5\r\nb4f23a88de9b566ce980a8188674319039d2fbe13b049859f8fe4821c92f9200\r\n3f3fb70e16d65f5f4b21777b87c9aae6072022c3dfbefd177f37c8aef4a6aeee\r\n67379740ed15e8da8604cc1f0ea715c8641674de66e553c461b3ae782a5d0cbe\r\nab3d61a76197003822252124e89987d061d6a4a33b9891cea778d3708cd50447\r\n6f654198e8efd5aff1c7a903353967d0e96aeff0402cb0a79fabbc10d18c63d2\r\nc288c200cf7bbebe7a81fd42ca1bd4c6cb6080f28f2cec297a0d3e6aff7876fe\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tNew Mirai Variant Targeting Network Security Devices - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tMirai Variant MooBot Targeting D-Link Devices - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tNetwork Security Trends: August-October 2022 - Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n\r\nAppendix\r\nCampaign-related vulnerability information is listed below:\r\n\r\nCVE-2012-4869: FreePBX Elastix Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThis malicious traffic was first detected as part of the V3G4 campaign on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets a command injection vulnerability in the FreePBX Elastix callme_startcall function, which does not successfully sanitize the user input in the callmenum parameter, leading to arbitrary command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126951\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 11. CVE-2012-4869 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nGitorious Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe captured this exploit traffic on July 4, 2022. The exploit works due to Gitorious\u2019 insufficient input validation, which allows the attacker to exploit the vulnerability to launch a command injection.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126953\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"590\"] Figure 12. Gitorious vulnerability exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2014-9727: FRITZ!Box Webcam Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe observed this malicious traffic on July 4, 2022. This remote command execution vulnerability is due to a failure to sanitize the value of the var:lang parameter in the cgi-bin\/webcm interface of the FRITZ!Box Webcam.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126955\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 13. CVE-2014-9727 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nMitel AWC Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThis exploit traffic was detected on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets a remote command execution vulnerability in the Mitel audio, web and video conferencing (AWC) product. The server fails to adequately sanitize the user-supplied input data, which leads to remote command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126957\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 14. Mitel AWC exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2017-5173: Geutebruck IP Cameras Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe detected this exploit traffic on July 4, 2022. The user input to Geutebruck IP Cameras\u2019 testaction.cgi component is not correctly sanitized, allowing the attacker to run shell commands with root privilege.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126959\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 15. CVE-2017-5173 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2019-15107: Webmin Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThis malicious traffic was detected on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets a command injection vulnerability in the password_change.cgi component within the Webmin product. The component does not successfully sanitize the parameters, which in turn can lead to arbitrary command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126961\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 16. CVE-2019-15107 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nSpree Commerce Arbitrary Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe observed this exploit traffic on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets the Spree Commerce product\u2019s insufficient input validation, the attacker can exploit the vulnerability to launch a remote command execution attack.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126963\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 17. Spree Commerce exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFLIR Thermal Camera Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThis exploit traffic was captured on July 4, 2022. The exploit works due to the FLIR Thermal Camera failing to sanitize user input, which in turn could lead to remote command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126965\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 18. FLIR Thermal Camera exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2020-8515: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe captured this exploit traffic on Sep. 13, 2022. The exploit targets the cgi-bin\/mainfunction.cgi component of DrayTek Vigor. The component does not successfully sanitize the value of the HTTP parameter keyPath, which leads to remote command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126967\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 19. CVE-2020-8515 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2020-15415: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n\r\nThis malicious traffic was captured on Sep. 13, 2022. The exploit works due to the \/cgi-bin\/mainfunction.cgi\/cvmcfgupload endpoint of DrayTek Vigor failing to sanitize the value of the HTTP parameter filename.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126969\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 20. CVE-2020-15415 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2022-36267: Airspan AirSpot Remote Command Execution Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe detected this exploit traffic on Sep. 14, 2022. The exploit targets a remote command execution vulnerability in the Airspan AirSpot cgi-bin\/diagnostics.cgi component. The component does not successfully sanitize the value of the HTTP parameter targetIP in the pingDiagnostic command.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126971\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 21. CVE-2022-36267 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2022-26134: Atlassian Confluence Remote Code Execution Vulnerability \r\n\r\nThis exploit traffic was captured on Sep. 12, 2022. An Object-Graph Navigation Language (OGNL) injection vulnerability exists in the Confluence Server and Data Center that would allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on a Confluence Server or Data Center instance.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126973\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"744\"] Figure 22. CVE-2022-26134 exploit in the wild.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCVE-2022-4257: C-Data Web Management System Command Injection Vulnerability\r\n\r\nWe observed this malicious traffic on Dec. 25, 2022. The exploit targets a remote code execution vulnerability in the diagnosis_config_save.php component of the C-Data Web management system. The component does not properly sanitize the values of the HTTP parameters iface and hostname, which in turn can lead to arbitrary command execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126975\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"630\"] Figure 23. C-Data RCE vulnerability exploits traffic.[\/caption]","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Chao Lei"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Zhibin Zhang"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Cecilia Hu"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Aveek Das"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<style id='co-authors-plus-coauthors-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow [class*=wp-block-co-authors-plus]{display:inline}

</style>
<style id='co-authors-plus-avatar-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar :where(img){height:auto;max-width:100%;vertical-align:bottom}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow .wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar :where(img){vertical-align:middle}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar:is(.alignleft,.alignright){display:table}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-avatar.aligncenter{display:table;margin-inline:auto}

</style>

.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image{margin-bottom:0}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image :where(img){height:auto;max-width:100%;vertical-align:bottom}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow .wp-block-co-authors-plus-image :where(img){vertical-align:middle}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image:is(.alignfull,.alignwide) :where(img){width:100%}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image:is(.alignleft,.alignright){display:table}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image.aligncenter{display:table;margin-inline:auto}

</style>

		}
	  </style>      <link rel="icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" sizes="32x32" />
<link rel="icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" sizes="192x192" />
<link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" />
<meta name="msapplication-TileImage" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" />
<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Chao Lei" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/chao-lei/">Chao Lei</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Zhibin Zhang" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/zhibin-zhang/">Zhibin Zhang</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Cecilia Hu" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/mengying-hu/">Cecilia Hu</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Aveek Das" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/aveek-das/">Aveek Das</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>15 February, 2023 at 6:00 AM PST</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Threat Research" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/">Threat Research</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Vulnerabilities" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/">Vulnerabilities</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:botnet" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/botnet/">Botnet</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:IoT Vulnerability" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/iot-vulnerability/">IoT Vulnerability</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:Mirai variant" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mirai-variant/">Mirai variant</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:V3G4" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/v3g4/">V3G4</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-v3g4/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/mirai-variant-v3g4/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>

      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/mirai-variant-v3g4/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-126924-_ruyyl6wo0i0m"></a>Content Warning</h2>
<p>We are providing a content warning because the following contains usage of a racial slur by a threat actor, which is not condoned in any instance by Unit 42. Unit 42 has partially redacted the racial slur to provide researchers with the ability to identify it and check IoCs as needed.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126924-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>From July to December 2022, Unit 42 researchers observed a Mirai variant called V3G4, which was leveraging several vulnerabilities to spread itself. The vulnerabilities exploited include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2012-4869">CVE-2012-4869</a>: FreePBX Elastix Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/18393">Gitorious Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</a></li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2014-9727">CVE-2014-9727</a>: FRITZ!Box Webcam Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/15807">Mitel AWC Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</a></li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-5173">CVE-2017-5173</a>: Geutebruck IP Cameras Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2019-15107">CVE-2019-15107</a>: Webmin Command Injection Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110726024546/http://www.spreecommerce.com/blog/2011/04/19/security-fixes/">Spree Commerce Arbitrary Command Execution Vulnerability</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/42788">FLIR Thermal Camera Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</a></li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-8515">CVE-2020-8515:</a> DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-15415">CVE-2020-15415</a>: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Injection Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-36267">CVE-2022-36267</a>: Airspan AirSpot Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-26134">CVE-2022-26134</a>: Atlassian Confluence Remote Code Execution Vulnerability</li>
<li><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-4257">CVE-2022-4257</a>: C-Data Web Management System Command Injection Vulnerability</li>
</ul>
<p>Once the vulnerable devices are compromised, they will be fully controlled by attackers and become a part of the botnet. The threat actor has the capability to utilize those devices to conduct further attacks, such as distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks. The exploit attempts captured by Unit 42 researchers leverage the aforementioned vulnerabilities to spread V3G4, which targets exposed servers and networking devices running Linux.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> customers receive protections through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions">cloud-delivered security services</a> such as <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/smart-devices-smarter-iot-security?utm_source=google-jg-amer-cdss&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_term=palo%20alto%20networks%20iot%20security&amp;utm_campaign=google-cdss-iot_security-amer-ca-awareness-en&amp;utm_content=gs-19633824690-151442986731-646705931499&amp;sfdcid=7014u000001hHCRAA2&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI1Lm26OmS_QIVQUNyCh1G3gKWEAAYASAAEgJ3KvD_BwE">IoT Security</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention">Advanced Threat Prevention</a>, <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire">WildFire</a>, and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering">Advanced URL Filtering</a>, which can help detect and block the exploit traffic and malware.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mirai-variant/"><b>Mirai</b></a><b>, </b><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/iot/"><b>IoT</b></a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-126924-_h9a06pchieml"></a>Campaign Overview</h2>
<p>Since July 2022, Unit 42 researchers have observed three campaigns utilizing the Mirai V3G4 variant. Based on our analysis, we believe the campaigns were operated by the same threat actor for the following reasons:</p>
<ul>
<li>The hardcoded command and control (C2) domains among these three campaigns contain the same string (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8xl9</span>)</li>
<li>The malware shell script downloaders are almost identical between the three campaigns</li>
<li>The botnet client samples use the same XOR decryption key</li>
<li>The botnet client samples use the same “stop list” (a list of target processes that the botnet client searches for and terminates)</li>
<li>The botnet client samples use almost identical functions</li>
</ul>
<p>The threat actor exploited 13 vulnerabilities that could lead to remote code execution. Upon successful exploitation, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wget</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">curl</span> utilities are automatically executed to download Mirai client samples from malware infrastructure and then execute the downloaded bot clients.</p>
<p>The utilized vulnerabilities are listed in Figure 1 below, and the detailed vulnerability information is listed in the <a href="#post-126924-_ajb20h1i7fau">Appendix</a> section.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126929" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126929" style="width: 781px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126929" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-1.png" alt="Image 1 is a timeline overview of the V3G4 campaign. For each of the three campaigns it lists the callback IP, the botnet C2, the month and year, and the exploited vulnerabilities. The campaigns were in July, September, and December of 2022. " width="781" height="478" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126929" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. V3G4 Campaign Overview.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-126924-_5q6cacqttrf1"></a>V3G4 Malware Analysis</h2>
<p>Based on behavior and patterns Unit 42 researchers observed during analysis of the downloaded botnet client samples, we believe that the botnet sample is a variant of the Mirai botnet.</p>
<p>Upon execution, the botnet client prints <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">xXxSlicexXxxVEGA</span>. to the console. The malware also contains a function that makes sure only one instance of this malware is executing on the infected device. If a botnet process already exists, the botnet client will simply print a string from the console and exit, as depicted in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126931" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126931" style="width: 266px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126931" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-2.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of the botnet printing a string from the console. " width="266" height="148" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126931" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. V3G4 ensures single instance execution.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The botnet client also contains a list of process names, and it tries to terminate those processes by checking the running process names on the infected host. The process names in that list belong to other botnet malware families and other Mirai variants. The full stop list is shown in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126933" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126933" style="width: 670px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126933" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-3.png" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of the full stop list of V3G4. " width="670" height="96" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126933" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. V3G4’s stop list.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The V3G4 variant tries to connect to its hardcoded C2. This activity is shown in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126935" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126935" style="width: 473px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126935" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-4.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of many lines of code where the V3G4 variant is trying to connect to the hardcoded C2." width="473" height="173" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126935" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. V3G4 malware C2 domain.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Most Mirai variants use the same key for string encryption. However, this V3G4 variant uses different XOR encryption keys for different scenarios.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126924-_gnm401264jq1"></a><strong>Botnet Client Execution-Related String Decryption</strong></h3>
<p>For strings related to botnet client execution, this V3G4 variant will first initialize an encrypted string table. It will then retrieve the encrypted string through an index (shown in Figures 5 and 6).</p>
<figure id="attachment_126937" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126937" style="width: 535px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126937" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-5.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of the V3G4’s initialization of an encrypted string table." width="535" height="267" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126937" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Encrypted string table.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_126939" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126939" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126939" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-6.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of V3G4’s retrieved strings from the encrypted string table. Highlighted is the line where V3G4 retrieves strings from the index." width="900" height="420" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126939" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. V3G4 retrieves strings.</figcaption></figure>
<p>All the botnet client execution-related strings are decrypted with four rounds of XOR decryption (shown in Figure 7). The decryption keys used are the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>First round: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xbc</span></li>
<li>Second round: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x69</span></li>
<li>Third round: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x3a</span></li>
<li>Fourth round: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xe6</span></li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_126941" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126941" style="width: 469px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126941" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-7.png" alt="Image 7 is a screenshot of four rounds of XOR decryption by V3G4 using the keys 0xbc, 0x69, 0x3a and 0xe6." width="469" height="208" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126941" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. V3G4 four rounds of XOR decryption.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-126924-_zgzyg4n1gefe"></a><strong>Brute Force Credential String Decryption</strong></h3>
<p>V3G4 inherits its most significant feature from the original Mirai variant – a data section with embedded default login credentials for the scanner and brute force purposes. Like the original Mirai, it also encrypts all credentials with XOR key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x37</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126943" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126943" style="width: 300px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126943" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-8.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of V3G4’s encrypting credentials with XOR key 0x37. " width="300" height="73" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126943" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. V3G4 credentials XOR Decryption.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The V3G4 variant initializes the table of telnet/SSH login credentials in the scanner function. It then spreads itself through brute forcing network devices’ weak username/password combinations.</p>
<p>Before the botnet client establishes a connection with the C2 server, the malware will first initialize all DDoS attack functions (shown in Figure 9). Once the client establishes a connection with the C2 server, the threat actor can issue commands to the client to launch DDoS attacks.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126945" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126945" style="width: 258px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126945" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-9.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of the malware’s DDoS attack functions. Four of them are highlighted in red, all starting with “attack.” " width="258" height="676" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126945" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. V3G4 DDoS functions.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We also noticed that the malware samples from the three campaigns we observed are slightly different. The original Mirai botnet sample spread itself by brute-forcing weak telnet/SSH credentials, whereas some Mirai variants utilize both brute-force and embedded exploits to spread themselves. However, samples from the September and December 2022 campaigns don’t contain the functions of vulnerability exploitation and brute force of credentials (this is shown in Figure 10).</p>
<figure id="attachment_126947" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126947" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126947" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-10.png" alt="Image 10 is a sample comparison of the July and December campaigns. Highlighted in the July campaign in red with an arrow is “scanner_init()”." width="900" height="229" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126947" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Campaign samples comparison.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-126924-_gbzm779wxlu7"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>The vulnerabilities mentioned above have less attack complexity than previously observed variants, but they maintain a critical security impact that can lead to remote code execution. Once the attacker gains control of a vulnerable device in this manner, they could take advantage by including the newly compromised devices in their botnet to conduct further attacks such as DDoS. Therefore, it is highly recommended that patches and updates are applied when possible.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protection from the vulnerabilities and malware discussed above through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewalls</a> with a Threat Prevention security subscription can help block the attacks with Best Practices via Threat Prevention signatures <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=56254">56254</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=56954">56954</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=92632">92632</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=55935">55935</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=55933">55933</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=58668">58668</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=35131">35131</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=55798">55798</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=57897">57897</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=56256">56256</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=55934">55934</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=93332">93332</a> and <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=93392">93392</a>.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention">Advanced Threat Prevention</a> has an inbuilt machine learning-based detection that can detect vulnerability exploits in real-time.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a> can help stop the malware with static signature detections.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security">DNS Security</a> are able to block the C2 domain and malware-hosting URLs.</li>
<li>The Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/smart-devices-smarter-iot-security?utm_source=google-jg-amer-cdss&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_term=palo%20alto%20networks%20iot%20security&amp;utm_campaign=google-cdss-iot_security-amer-ca-awareness-en&amp;utm_content=gs-19633824690-151442986731-646705931499&amp;sfdcid=7014u000001hHCRAA2&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI1Lm26OmS_QIVQUNyCh1G3gKWEAAYASAAEgJ3KvD_BwE">IoT Security</a> platform can leverage network traffic information to identify the vendor, model and firmware version of a device and identify specific devices that are vulnerable to particular CVEs.</li>
<li>In addition, IoT Security has inbuilt machine learning-based anomaly detection that can alert the customer if a device exhibits nontypical behavior such as a sudden appearance of traffic from a new source, an unusually high number of connections or an inexplicable surge of certain attributes typically appearing in IoT application payloads.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-126924-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<h3><a id="post-126924-_9g3ttp9x889g"></a>Infrastructure</h3>
<h4><a id="post-126924-_n1o2mdc8sm1g"></a>Malware C2</h4>
<p><img decoding="async" class="alignleft wp-image-126949" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-11.png" alt="IoCs with slur removed" width="210" height="49" /></p>
<h4></h4>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace; color: #ffffff;">comeanalyze.8x19[.]com</span></p>
<h4><a id="post-126924-_857yeil2hlz1"></a>Malware Host</h4>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">176.123.9[.]238<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">198.98.49[.]79<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">104.244.72[.]64</span></p>
<h3><a id="post-126924-_d6j1msoh6o9l"></a>Artifacts</h3>
<h4><a id="post-126924-_xp4x53e388a3"></a>Shell Script Downloader</h4>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0837de91aa6bd52ef79d744daba4238a5a48a79eb91cb1a727da3e97d5b36329<br />
</span></span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c32f8df3cb019e83e0ac49ab0462c59ec70733c3d516ade011727408751c9d42<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f295904d966889afb0f6b3625e504a1420a978434e2b6a9e9b85b688a44593fa</span></p>
<h4><a id="post-126924-_j3vgh7d3fz9e"></a>V3G4 Sample</h4>
<p>July Campaign</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7bc99c87a1e0582b5f15f40141226862fbe726b496e1e77c7f95993e8e945733<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">88f7b9a8c4f9bb28582c485549b328d6123e8aea33009ce7657f7fc0ef829e03<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64545e94daafba191669333e1dd0c6e1190df47e0742bd515911cce0cdbd4fd1<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">69bb44736817dabe88e3014c6207ba702f644fb43f6feaec23091af0b5224bc6<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eaa387fcc12f2d8a7d42f12d27e7dccb4f3e11492a7d3a3a1ce830a11b539d28<br />

</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b651f9320f07d7eade9af523297b4bcfd0e0af187272e368e889c988a55ed78e<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6229041985c466c131e48b9ba0d1bb80bdb7556c941ee84aa461fe2efbf1e853<br />

</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a93d999dc0515066c5c2a261f1be47233b358889d0594c14409309818d86347d</span></p>
<p>September Campaign</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">31926da5ca004a11c1f46947edb220afe3a53f81cf245b3afae7ea1abaec7c38<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eed4690f6e4d92b511fcde9a712b1a8405c5333e0ad78a4c676a64b22412e149<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">210f3f1ffd2ec66a5076a7fea5d83caa8bbcdb0f3bc3bd030c77eded6f4b5d90<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">73cc00acc478bf09658a679a4689f34598fe6e92086efe82900242f3cc5b7aec<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1218da43a62da76927484bca73a3eee53425c54625147f8d01149bcef2f09d1e<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2944db28e4505fc439599dae15b10bf57b7cf6c2597f618f41b99bfc65443c61<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4bffc171c0748cc9e3398b1ce8135b125f54f46752768c981c45d3390e8359a1<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b3a17934f6f72941b9a60097ab09228d873a2f8737ee0ea93b08e5f1cc3916d1<br />

<p>December Campaign:</p>

</ul>
<h2><a id="post-126924-_ajb20h1i7fau"></a>Appendix</h2>
<p>Campaign-related vulnerability information is listed below:</p>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2012-4869"><strong>CVE-2012-4869</strong></a><strong>: FreePBX Elastix Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>This malicious traffic was first detected as part of the V3G4 campaign on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets a command injection vulnerability in the FreePBX Elastix <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">callme_startcall</span> function, which does not successfully sanitize the user input in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">callmenum</span> parameter, leading to arbitrary command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126951" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126951" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126951" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-12.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2012-4869 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="140" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126951" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. CVE-2012-4869 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/18393"><strong>Gitorious Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></a></p>
<p>We captured this exploit traffic on July 4, 2022. The exploit works due to Gitorious’ insufficient input validation, which allows the attacker to exploit the vulnerability to launch a command injection.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126953" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126953" style="width: 590px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126953" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-13.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the Gitorious vulnerability exploit in the wild." width="590" height="126" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126953" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Gitorious vulnerability exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2014-9727"><strong>CVE-2014-9727</strong></a><strong>: FRITZ!Box Webcam Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>We observed this malicious traffic on July 4, 2022. This remote command execution vulnerability is due to a failure to sanitize the value of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">var:lang</span> parameter in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cgi-bin/webcm</span> interface of the FRITZ!Box Webcam.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126955" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126955" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126955" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-14.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2014-9727 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="117" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126955" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. CVE-2014-9727 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/15807"><strong>Mitel AWC Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></a></p>
<p>This exploit traffic was detected on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets a remote command execution vulnerability in the Mitel audio, web and video conferencing (AWC) product. The server fails to adequately sanitize the user-supplied input data, which leads to remote command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126957" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126957" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126957" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-15.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the Mitel AWC exploit in the wild." width="744" height="138" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126957" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Mitel AWC exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-5173"><strong>CVE-2017-5173</strong></a><strong>: Geutebruck IP Cameras Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>We detected this exploit traffic on July 4, 2022. The user input to Geutebruck IP Cameras’ <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">testaction.cgi</span> component is not correctly sanitized, allowing the attacker to run shell commands with root privilege.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126959" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126959" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126959" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-16.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2017-5173 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="168" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126959" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. CVE-2017-5173 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2019-15107"><strong>CVE-2019-15107</strong></a><strong>: Webmin Command Injection Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>This malicious traffic was detected on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets a command injection vulnerability in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">password_change.cgi</span> component within the Webmin product. The component does not successfully sanitize the parameters, which in turn can lead to arbitrary command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126961" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126961" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126961" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-17.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2019-15107 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="148" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126961" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. CVE-2019-15107 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110726024546/http://www.spreecommerce.com/blog/2011/04/19/security-fixes/"><strong>Spree Commerce Arbitrary Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></a></p>
<p>We observed this exploit traffic on July 4, 2022. The exploit targets the Spree Commerce product’s insufficient input validation, the attacker can exploit the vulnerability to launch a remote command execution attack.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126963" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126963" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126963" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-18.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the Spree Commerce exploit in the wild." width="744" height="146" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126963" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Spree Commerce exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/42788"><strong>FLIR Thermal Camera Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></a></p>
<p>This exploit traffic was captured on July 4, 2022. The exploit works due to the FLIR Thermal Camera failing to sanitize user input, which in turn could lead to remote command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126965" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126965" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126965" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-19.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the FLIR Thermal Camera exploit in the wild." width="744" height="272" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126965" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. FLIR Thermal Camera exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-8515"><strong>CVE-2020-8515</strong></a><strong>: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>We captured this exploit traffic on Sep. 13, 2022. The exploit targets the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cgi-bin/mainfunction.cgi</span> component of DrayTek Vigor. The component does not successfully sanitize the value of the HTTP parameter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">keyPath</span>, which leads to remote command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126967" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126967" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126967" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-20.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2020-8515 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="195" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126967" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. CVE-2020-8515 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-15415"><strong>CVE-2020-15415</strong></a><strong>: DrayTek Vigor Remote Command Injection Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>This malicious traffic was captured on Sep. 13, 2022. The exploit works due to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/cgi-bin/mainfunction.cgi/cvmcfgupload</span> endpoint of DrayTek Vigor failing to sanitize the value of the HTTP parameter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">filename</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126969" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126969" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126969" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-21.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2020-15415 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="227" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126969" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 20. CVE-2020-15415 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-36267"><strong>CVE-2022-36267</strong></a><strong>: Airspan AirSpot Remote Command Execution Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>We detected this exploit traffic on Sep. 14, 2022. The exploit targets a remote command execution vulnerability in the Airspan AirSpot <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cgi-bin/diagnostics.cgi</span> component. The component does not successfully sanitize the value of the HTTP parameter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">targetIP</span> in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pingDiagnostic</span> command.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126971" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126971" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126971" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-22.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2022-36267 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="273" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126971" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 21. CVE-2022-36267 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-26134"><strong>CVE-2022-26134</strong></a><strong>: Atlassian Confluence Remote Code Execution Vulnerability </strong></p>
<p>This exploit traffic was captured on Sep. 12, 2022. An Object-Graph Navigation Language (OGNL) injection vulnerability exists in the Confluence Server and Data Center that would allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on a Confluence Server or Data Center instance.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126973" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126973" style="width: 744px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126973" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-23.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the CVE-2022-26134 exploit in the wild." width="744" height="162" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126973" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 22. CVE-2022-26134 exploit in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-4257"><strong>CVE-2022-4257</strong></a><strong>: C-Data Web Management System Command Injection Vulnerability</strong></p>
<p>We observed this malicious traffic on Dec. 25, 2022. The exploit targets a remote code execution vulnerability in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">diagnosis_config_save.php</span> component of the C-Data Web management system. The component does not properly sanitize the values of the HTTP parameters <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">iface</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hostname</span>, which in turn can lead to arbitrary command execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126975" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126975" style="width: 630px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126975" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/word-image-126924-24.png" alt="A few lines of code showing the C-Data RCE vulnerability exploit in the wild." width="630" height="253" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126975" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 23. C-Data RCE vulnerability exploits traffic.</figcaption></figure>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 June, 2024 at 12:23 PM PDT</span>-->
              <button class="l-btn back-to-top" id="backToTop" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:back to top">Back to top</button>
              
			<div class="be__tags-wrapper"> 
				<h3>Tags</h3><ul role="list"><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/botnet/" role="link" title="botnet" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:tags:botnet">Botnet</a></li><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/iot-vulnerability/" role="link" title="IoT Vulnerability" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:tags:IoT Vulnerability">IoT Vulnerability</a></li><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mirai-variant/" role="link" title="Mirai variant" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:tags:Mirai variant">Mirai variant</a></li><li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/v3g4/" role="link" title="V3G4" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="mirai-variant-v3g4:tags:V3G4">V3G4</a></li></ul>
			</div>
